{{Infobox musical artist | name = Bonnie Lee | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Jessie Lee Frealls | alias = Bonnie Lee Murray
Bonnie "Bombshell" Lane
'Sweetheart of the Blues' | birth_date = {{birth date|1931|6|11|mf=y}} |birth_place =[[Bunkie, Louisiana|Bunkie]], [[Louisiana]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|2006|9|7|1931|6|11|mf=y}} |death_place =[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Chicago blues]], [[soul-blues]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]] | years_active = Late 1950s–2006 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Bonnie Lee''' (June 11, 1931 – September 7, 2006) was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] [[singing|singer]]. Known as 'Sweetheart of the Blues', she is best remembered for her lengthy working relationships with [[Sunnyland Slim]] and [[Willie Kent]].[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2006b.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com - accessed January 2010] David Whiteis, who interviewed Lee in researching his book, ''Chicago Blues: Portraits and Stories'' stated, "she was one of the last of her genre, the big-voiced woman blues singer fronting a Chicago band." ==Biography== She was born '''Jessie Lee Frealls''' in [[Bunkie, Louisiana|Bunkie]], [[Louisiana]], [[United States]], and raised in [[Beaumont, Texas|Beaumont]], [[Texas]].{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p34174/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Bonnie Lee |author=Ankeny, Jason |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=January 19, 2010}} After learning to play the piano as a child, her mother refused to let her join [[gospel music|gospel]] singer [[Lillian Glinn]] on tour. Instead she did later tour with the Famous Georgia Minstrels, meeting both [[Clarence "Gatemouth" Brown]] and [[Big Mama Thornton]]. In 1958 she moved to [[Chicago]], and chose the [[stage name]] of Bonnie Lee, working as both a [[dancer]] and singer. Two years later she signed a [[recording contract]] with [[J. Mayo Williams]]' Ebony Records [[record label|label]]. The downside was Williams' insistence on her being billed as Bonnie "Bombshell" Lane on her first [[single (music)|single]], "Sad and Evil Woman." It was a name she disliked but, after the single failed to sell, she returned to the Chicago [[jazz]] and blues [[nightclub]]s. She was later billed as Bonnie Lee Murray, using her then husband's surname. In 1967 Lee first appeared on the bill with the [[pianist]] [[Sunnyland Slim]], and their working arrangement included residencies at a number of Chicago clubs. This led her, at the end of the 1970s, to release further singles via the Slim owned record label, Airway Records. After suffering health problems at the end of that decade, Lee then enjoyed a long professional partnership with [[Willie Kent]]. For many years the combination of Lee backed by Willie Kent and the Gents, became a regular feature in B.L.U.E.S., a noted Chicago club. There she sang her most famous numbers; "I’m Good" and "[[Need Your Love So Bad]]."{{cite web |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/2006/sep/13/news/chi-0609130082sep13|title=Bonnie Lee: 1931 - 2006|author=Jensen, Trevor |publisher=[[Chicago Tribune]] |accessdate=January 19, 2010}} In 1982, and partnered with [[Zora Young]] and [[Big Time Sarah]] as 'Blues with the Girls', Lee toured [[Europe]] and cut a joint album in [[Paris]], [[France]].{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 195 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} In 1992 Lee guested on [[Magic Slim]]'s album, ''44 Blues,'' with [[John Primer]]. Finally in her own name, in 1995 [[Delmark Records]] released, ''Sweetheart of the Blues'', and three years later another collection, ''I'm Good'', was issued. In September 2006, after years of poor health, Lee died at the age of 75. ==Partial discography== {| class="wikitable" !Year !Title !Label |- |1995 |''Sweetheart of the Blues'' |[[Delmark Records|Delmark]] |- |1998 |''I'm Good: Chicago Blues Session, Volume 7'' |Wolf Records |- |}{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p34174/discography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( Bonnie Lee > Discography > Main Albums )))}} ==See also== *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://hubcap.clemson.edu/~campber/ebony.html Illustrated discography at Hubcap.clemson.edu] *[http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/i-need-someones-hand/Content?oid=881318 David Whiteis, "'I Need Someone's Hand' - Bonnie Lee's Life in the Blues"], ''[[Chicago Reader]]'' article and interview, February 4, 1993 {{Persondata | NAME =Lee, Bonnie | ALTERNATIVE NAMES =Frealls, Jessie Lee | SHORT DESCRIPTION =[[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] singer | DATE OF BIRTH =June 11, 1931 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Bunkie, Louisiana]], United States | DATE OF DEATH =September 7, 2006 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lee, Bonnie}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American female singers]] [[Category:Chicago blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Louisiana]] [[Category:Soul-blues musicians]] [[Category:People from Beaumont, Texas]] [[Category:People from Avoyelles Parish, Louisiana]]
